posts.name: IowaICE
posts.cooked:
Does Your NOCO battery charger charge the batteries to 13.4 V?

We have not been able to get it to the full 13.4 V

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: I haven’t checked. I think that’s as much of a function of the battery chemistry as the charger.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: What mode are you charging the batteries in?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
We’ve had bad experiences with the Noco chargers after we built a new cart around them pre champs. We’ve been having to top off batteries with the old chargers and it really blows.

Will be keeping an eye on this thread

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: I just happen to have an FRC battery charging on a NOCO Genius 5 in my garage. The charger claims the battery is charged (probably was yesterday), and the terminal voltage is reading 13.4 volts on my once calibrated Fluke 26 III.
A full charge on an AGM battery is 12.8 volts. Anything after that is just surface charge.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Some people call me the Space Cowboy

posts.custom_user_title: Some people call me the Space Cowboy

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked: I’ve heard the “NOCO doesn’t surface charge” point being made a ton of times but the reality is, at least with our robot, we would not make it through a full match on a NOCO charged battery, while we would on a battery fresh off the pro chargers. Of course, there’s a ton of variance between batteries but we do track everything and this was what we saw in our logs at practice and CMP as a general trend.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Can you post any of the data? Is it discharge only or do you have any charge data?

Specs wise the noco should be about the same performance.

Brand wise I trust/have more confidence in noco being a quality product over the pro brand. Although charging lead acid is a well known profile and there is little to no merit to any particular brands “snake oil” or “secret sauce”.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I have a noco 10a on my boat and it goes up to 13.4 at least before reaching saturation charge and settling down to 13.2 to hold for long term storage.

I’ll work to get some charging graphs over the next few months

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked: Noticing similar issues on our Noco 5x3 setup, some of the batteries are getting up to 12.9 but most settle near 12.6 (Battery Beak 3rd line, iirc 18A load, will confirm). Haven’t tried to profile the batteries or compare to previous chargers yet.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked: @Clodsire has it right.  The topic is pretty well covered in this thread . Please look at the discharge graph I shared in this post which shows just how quickly that surface charge dissipates.  You are not putting a meaningful amount of additional energy into the battery just because it reads an artificially high voltage value fresh off (some) chargers.

link_counts.title: What battery chargers do you use?
What battery chargers do you use?

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
We have two of the NOCO Genius GEN5X chargers and they work well for us.

I’ve seen more issues with battery internal resistance changes between charging cycles though.

As a result, we started detailed logging of pre and post match charge levels.

All of this was implemented during off season events.

This additional screening improved our in-match performance.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: Same question for your team, what mode is the charger set to when you are using it? Based on what AndyMark has stated, it should be set to AGM mode for the batteries we use.
